subject: Home Again
event:
Back from Texas.  I had a marvelous time at Texas A&M, presenting them with the five millionth volume for their library, a first edition of THE HOBBIT, and at the Nacogdoches Film Festival, where I got to see my old friends Howard Waldrop, Michael Cassutt, and Joe R. Lansdale, and make a whole bunch of new friends besides.  Did some business too, discussing a very cool new project I am working on with H'ard, Mike, and Joe R.  More on that later.

But not I am home again, facing the usual mountain of mail and email, and of course the monkeys on my back... those noisiest of them being HIGH STAKES, volume twenty-three in the Wild Cards series, and of course the Son of Kong, THE WINDS OF WINTER.

Once more into the breach...

comments.article: I've always wanted to have a really nice leather bound, gold trimmed edition of the Hobbit and Lord of the Rings to display. 1st editions would be just to much to handle, haha. I plan on getting a complete set of ASoIaF (when the time comes)
comments.subject: 1st Editions (or just cool ones)

comments.article: Hi George, just wanted to say thank you for all the hard work you put into creating these amazing literary works for our enjoyment. The dedication you have for your projects is evident purely from the high quality of work you have presented to your readers. I feel like this dedication can sometimes be overlooked and I wanted you to know that it is appreciated greatly! Hope you find some time to relax after your travels. Thanks again
comments.subject: Dedication

comments.article: First Edition of The Hobbit?!  That was a most generous gift, Ser!  I don't know if I could bring myself to part with the same.
Isn't it a pain when real life gets in the way of writing?  Back to the keyboard, all of us writers.

Didn't Son of Kong come out soon after King Kong?

JK/lol
comments.subject: Son of Kong

comments.article:
hi George,

Thanks for all the great work.

Since you mention the son of kong I thought I might actually try to get some answers on some "fun" questions I had.

Would you actually consider using some of, say, the telltale game's characters and use these into the upcoming books or more generally characters from any other semi canon source?

And will there again be some wildly inappropriate degrading "Easter egg" references included of sports teams that are of your particular disliking?

Keep up the great work and excited for what is coming next
comments.subject: The son of Kong

comments.article: As a lot of fans I hope, son is more appeasable than his father. Have a good time and pleasure from the work!
OMG! Thank you sir for coming to Texas! I came to your book signing at Hastings it was an out of world experience to see you and get my book signed I still cannot believe it!! Wow!!!
comments.subject: Book signing

comments.article:
If Winds of Winter is the Son of Kong, what will that make Dream of Spring? I don't think there was ever a Grandson of Kong. Maybe Donkey Kong?

Someone needs to release a version of Donkey Kong with you replacing Mario and other books and obligations replacing the barrels he throws to slow you down.
It would be Mighty Joe Young!
Write at the pace you need, Mr. Martin. We're behind you.
comments.subject: You can do it!

comments.article: Out of curiosity, was that a US or UK 1st edition?
comments.subject: Hobbit

comments.article:
Every time you start talking about monkeys on your back, it makes me think of your old story "The Monkey Treatment".

I know you hate it when people ask you about how far you have come or how much remains and so on, so I'm not gonna ask. But are there any kind of questions regarding Wind of Winter you don't mind that much? Like; are you facing some of the same problems you had when writing the two previous novels, or is this one easier to write?

Best of luck George! I can only hope you'll be able to enjoy writing TWoW for as long as it takes, away from the ridiculous pressure that the success of the show has brought you.

In the meantime, I'll be re-reading and re-reading and re-reading and probably over-analyzing the first five books until Son of Kong gets off your back and graces my shelf :)

Good luck with Winds! If it helps at all you have your diehard fans wishing you well every step of the way. The big Facebook fan group is almost 40000 members strong, with a good core of regulars who chat about the books and sometimes the show on a largely daily basis. Most venerate the books above the show and other tie ins though.

I have been a fan of ASOIAF since 1998. Your books have always been there for me throughout my adult life. I appreciate that and look forward to many more. Besides Winds, I am looking forward to the graphic novel of The Mystery Knight. :)
George, how many Cowboys fans did you encounter other than myself?  Haha.  My wife was before me in line with a copy of the Ice Dragon.  We are reading it to our kids and they love it!
comments.subject: Cowboys fans.

comments.article: Take a day off George. We can wait.

We can't wait! We're writhing on our floors, foaming and gnawing on our extra paperback copies for some relief from the agony, by funder.

This dreadful torment aside, I really can't fathom the vicious whinging about it, as if people are somehow unable to look at publication dates and comprehend that 'A Song of Ice and Fire' is actually coming out at, hey, the same pace it was coming out at before the show began. Or they could look at bloody Wikipedia and read that the first one took longer to produce than we've been waiting for 'Winds.' I warn my friends that the Ethiopian restaurant takes a long time to prepare your meal, and that Ethiopian restaurants are known for this. I don't sit at the table there and complain about it, much less harass the lady who cooks there.

Much as I'd love a new book right this very instant, I am sorry Mr. Martin has been subjected to this rudeness.
Godspeed quillmaster.

Thanx alot for al ya have done so far. first edition of The Hobbit... jealous is not even discribing the feeling. hence i see you are busy, hope you will have some spare time couse its no use to work you're self to destruction. Always on the road, Deepest respect toward you. Hoping ya keep hart in the middle, to keep aiming high. All the luck to ya.
comments.subject: dwarfslayer

comments.article:
Just curious : when you announce a release date for the Winds of Winter, how much time will it be before the actual release ?

Are we to expect around 8 months, like the announcement for A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms ?

Cheers from France !

Cheers, George.

Keep on the good work. Don't let others tell you what you need to write or when you need to write or how fast you need to write. It's your work and it's a lifetime work. You have the right to choose your approach. I, for one, support you :)
comments.subject: on writing the son of Kong

comments.article:
Do you have any idea what happens to all of us when you just type the words THE WINDS OF WINTER?

Chills....

And A DREAM OF SPRING would be Godzilla.

Q:

King Kong or Godzilla?
comments.subject: GODZILLA

comments.article: A very nice gift indeed!
comments.subject: Hobbit 1st

comments.article: I'm glad to see the monkey treatment in action.
comments.subject: Keep having fun

comments.upictitle: chris: say hello to my little friend
comments.article: "the Son of Kong AKA The Winds of Winter" should be a tweet heard 'round the world.

Son of Kong. Haha. Ah ha ha hahaha.

New title perhaps? I wonder if the publisher can be convinced...

The pressure and general PITA of constant fans pestering you over the release date of TWOW must be beyond the point of aggravation. George, you should impose a 20$ tax on anyone who brings it up from now on.

I recently had an argument/discussion with a friend, who was using the Tom Clancy argument, how CLancy from the late 80s until 2000 released a book every year or two that was >1000 pages. I pointed out that Clancy did this in the age before the internet picked up much steam, and was a recluse compared to Martin in terms of appearance commitments and such, which gave Clancy much more available time to write.

Please keep hunt/pecking away George, we love you, patience is a virtue, and personally I'm enjoying being surprised by the adaptation changes of the HBO program, so the whole show overtaking the books complaint isn't an issue for many like myself.
